channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Riverside County hospitals hit 99% capacity for ICUs. That's not their biggest problem
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: While Riverside County's ICU beds are nearly all taken, partly because of the coronavirus, the bigger challenge for health authorities is a staffing shortage.
item.content:encoded: While Riverside County's ICU beds are nearly all taken, partly because of the coronavirus, the bigger challenge for health authorities is a staffing shortage.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA- APRIL 8, 2020: Paramedics load Bernie Erwig, 84, into an ambulance while he was removed from Magnolia Rehabilitation and Nursing Center after 39 tested positive for coronavirus and nursing staff was not showing up to work for their own safety on April 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. All 84 residents were removed. Erwig tested positive for COVID-19 and was transferred to the county hospital in Moreno Valley, RUHS, where he spent 4 weeks recovering from the coronavirus. He is now home still recuperating. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 3 arrested on suspicion of murder in case of missing Coachella Valley couple
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: The Riverside County couple were last seen in May 2017. Three years later, three men have been arrested in the case.
item.content:encoded: The Riverside County couple were last seen in May 2017. Three years later, three men have been arrested in the case.

media:content.media:description: Jonathon Reynoso and Audrey Moran are seen in an undated handout photo. The couple went missing in 2017.

item.title: Newsom threatens to reverse California reopening as coronavirus spreads
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said the state is prepared to reinstate restrictions of his stay-at-home order as cases of the coronavirus continue to increase in California.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said the state is prepared to reinstate restrictions of his stay-at-home order as cases of the coronavirus continue to increase in California.

media:content.media:description: A man waits for a bus near a bar closed due to the coronavirus pandemic in Los Angeles, Monday, June 29, 2020. California Gov. Gavin Newsom on Sunday ordered bars that have opened in seven California counties, including Los Angeles, to immediately close and urged bars in eight other counties to do the same, saying the coronavirus was rapidly spreading in those parts of the state and that bar settings create a higher risk of transmission. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong)

item.title: Huizar, facing felony charge, will no longer receive L.A. council salary, official says
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser
item.description: L.A. City Controller Ron Galperin said it would be 'unacceptable' for Councilman Jose Huizar to continue earning his salary.
item.content:encoded: L.A. City Controller Ron Galperin said it would be 'unacceptable' for Councilman Jose Huizar to continue earning his salary.

media:content.media:description: City Controller Ron Galperin, at the mic, at Los Angeles City Hall East on May 22, 2015.

item.title: Seeking suspects, LAPD posts footage of people lighting fires, harming property during protests
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: The Los Angeles Police Department has posted images and video online of people doing damage and are asking the public to help ID suspects.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Police Department has posted images and video online of people doing damage and are asking the public to help ID suspects.

media:content.media:description: City Hall reflected on the Los Angeles Police Department headquarters in downtown Los Angeles on Friday, May 3, 2019. (Photo by Nick Agro / For The Times)

item.title: As social unrest swept L.A. a curious trend emerged: Calls for police plunged
item.dc:creator: Matt Stiles
item.description: Police say calls for service dropped possibly because residents were distracted by the demonstrations and some problems, by comparison, seemed "petty."
item.content:encoded: Police say calls for service dropped possibly because residents were distracted by the demonstrations and some problems, by comparison, seemed "petty."

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: LAPD officers surround protestors at Hollywood Blvd and Cahuenga Blvd and declare an unlawful assembley in Hollywood to control protestors made of mostly students as they marched Tuesday afternoon to protest the death of George Floyd during an arrest in Minneapolis last week. The group gathered at the intersection of Hollywood Blvd and Vine Street for a peaceful demonstration and marched through parts of Hollywood encountering LAPD officers and National Guardsmen. Hollywood on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County issues dire warning amid 'alarming increases' in coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: This is the scenario that L.A. County health officials most feared — that reopening would coincide with sudden jumps in coronavirus transmission.
item.content:encoded: This is the scenario that L.A. County health officials most feared — that reopening would coincide with sudden jumps in coronavirus transmission.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 25: People in downtown Los Angeles on Thursday, June 25, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Los Angeles County Is supposed to reach 90,000 active covid cases today and the state may reach 200,000 cases, with Mayor Eric Garcetti ca;;omg for Angelenos to stay indoors amid the surge in COVID-19 cases.

item.title: ER doctor charged in sexual assaults of four women
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Anshul Gandhi, 34, was charged Monday with four felony counts of sexual battery.
item.content:encoded: Anshul Gandhi, 34, was charged Monday with four felony counts of sexual battery.

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus cases surge past 100,000 with record one-day tally
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Maura Dolan
item.description: Los Angeles County confirmed 22 additional coronavirus-related deaths and 2,903 new coronavirus cases Monday.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County confirmed 22 additional coronavirus-related deaths and 2,903 new coronavirus cases Monday.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Sunday, June 28,2020 - Patrons of the Down'n'Out Sports Bar, drink at an outside patio. Governor Newsom orders bars to close as Covid-19 cases surge in California. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Brush fire in Imperial County destroys dozens of homes, officials say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A massive brush fire tore through Niland, Calif., east of the Salton Sea overnight, burning for hours and destroying about 40 homes, officials said.
item.content:encoded: A massive brush fire tore through Niland, Calif., east of the Salton Sea overnight, burning for hours and destroying about 40 homes, officials said.

item.title: LA schools reopening: 20% of parents, 36% of staff are not ready for campuses to open
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Even if campuses reopen in the fall, about 20% of L.A. parents and more than a third of school employees surveyed are not ready to return to campus.
item.content:encoded: Even if campuses reopen in the fall, about 20% of L.A. parents and more than a third of school employees surveyed are not ready to return to campus.

media:content.media:description: SAN FERNANDO, CA-APRIL 20, 2020: LAUSD Superintendent Austin Beutner wears a protective mask against the coronavirus, during a tour of one of the district's Grab & Go food centers at San Fernando Senior High School, where meals were given out to LAUSD students in need. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's slide from coronavirus success to danger zone began Memorial Day
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee, Sean Greene, Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: The Memorial Day weekend appears to have been the turning point that pushed California into the coronavirus surge it's seeing now.
item.content:encoded: The Memorial Day weekend appears to have been the turning point that pushed California into the coronavirus surge it's seeing now.

media:content.media:description: SAN DIEGO, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, APRIL 10, 2020: Wearing personal protective equipment, RN April Bandi, cares for a patient under investigation that have possible COVID-19 symptoms, inside a special negative pressure isolation room at the Emergency Department, at Sharp Memorial Hospital in San Diego, Calif., on April 10, 2020. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Marcus Yam/Los Angeles Times

item.title: In L.A., Black activists debate the value of dialogue with police in reform efforts
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Amid a movement for police reform, some Black leaders are trying to rebuild relationships with police. Others reject that dialogue
item.content:encoded: Amid a movement for police reform, some Black leaders are trying to rebuild relationships with police. Others reject that dialogue

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 12: Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore answers questions from the group at Abundant Life Christian Church on Friday, June 12, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Black community leaders are hoping to create meaningful change from George Floyd protests. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UCLA end-of-life program adapts during pandemic to help dying patients and their families
item.dc:creator: JoNel Aleccia
item.description: For three years, staff at UCLA Health have been quietly fulfilling final wishes for dying patients in the intensive care unit. Amid the pandemic, their work has taken on more meaning.
item.content:encoded: For three years, staff at UCLA Health have been quietly fulfilling final wishes for dying patients in the intensive care unit. Amid the pandemic, their work has taken on more meaning.

media:content.media:description: Patti Breed-Rabitoy had coped with lung and kidney disease for years but remained a vital, bubbly presence in the lives of her husband, Dan Rabitoy, and three grown children.

item.title: Online or in the classroom, teachers and students must show up every day, new rules say
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Paloma Esquivel
item.description: In normal times, it wouldn't seem to be asking a lot for teachers to take attendance and to teach on scheduled school days, but all that changed with the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: In normal times, it wouldn't seem to be asking a lot for teachers to take attendance and to teach on scheduled school days, but all that changed with the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: EL SEGUNDO, CA - JUNE 03: First Grade teacher Caitlin Hicks gives a "virtual hug" to Sid Solomon, 6 (7 in August), as she greets her students one final time, with social distance, picking up their years' work and see each other in person for the first time in months because of the coronavirus pandemic, at Center Street Elementary, in El Segundo, CA, on Wednesday, June 3, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's mask order tests the limits of Newsom's executive power
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Since shortly after the coronavirus outbreak began, Gov. Gavin Newsom has faced criticism from some over his ample use of executive authority during the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Since shortly after the coronavirus outbreak began, Gov. Gavin Newsom has faced criticism from some over his ample use of executive authority during the COVID-19 pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 18: Brandon Leslie, an RN working with COVID-19 patients at Good Samaritan Medical Center, wears a protective mask to help protect from contracting COVID-19, takes a walk by the Staples Center Thursday, June 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Gov. Gavin Newsom on Thursday ordered all Californians to wear face coverings while in public or high-risk settings, including when shopping, taking public transit or seeking medical care, following growing concerns that an increase in coronavirus cases has been caused by residents failing to voluntarily take that precaution. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Golden State Killer pleads guilty to crimes that terrorized California
item.dc:creator: Paige St. John, Luke Money
item.description: Victims watch as a former police officer admits to committing murders and rapes in the 1970s and 1980s.
item.content:encoded: Victims watch as a former police officer admits to committing murders and rapes in the 1970s and 1980s.

media:content.media:description: Joseph James DeAngelo, center, charged with being the Golden State Killer, is helped up by his attorney, Diane Howard, as Sacramento Superior Court Judge Michael Bowman enters the courtroom in Sacramento, Calif., Monday June 29, 2020. DeAngelo pleaded guilty to multiple counts of murder and other charges 40 years after a sadistic series of assaults and slayings in California. Due to the large numbers of people attending, the hearing was held at a ballroom at California State University, Sacramento to allow for social distancing. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: She's the first Black woman in the U.S. to lead a legislative house. Will Karen Bass soon be VP?
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Joe Biden's ticket could do far worse than adding Rep. Karen Bass of Los Angeles, who is smart, energetic and successful at achieving goals — including a guiding a police reform bill through the House.
item.content:encoded: Joe Biden's ticket could do far worse than adding Rep. Karen Bass of Los Angeles, who is smart, energetic and successful at achieving goals — including a guiding a police reform bill through the House.

media:content.media:description: From left, House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., Rep. Bobby Rush, D-Ill., House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, D-Md., and Rep. Karen Bass, D-Calif., chair of the Congressional Black Caucus, hold a news conference to discuss the "Emmett Till Antilynching Act" which would designate lynching as a hate crime under federal law, on Capitol Hill in Washington, Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2020. Emmett Till, pictured at right, was a 14-year-old African-American who was lynched in Mississippi in 1955, after being accused of offending a white woman in her family's grocery store. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)

item.title: Hugo's Tacos closes temporarily after employees are harassed by mask-averse patrons
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: Harassment ranging from racial epithets to drinks being hurled at workers has taken an emotional toll on the mostly Latino employees, Hugo's co-owner said.
item.content:encoded: Harassment ranging from racial epithets to drinks being hurled at workers has taken an emotional toll on the mostly Latino employees, Hugo's co-owner said.

media:content.media:description: Hugo's Tacos, a beloved Los Angeles Taco chain, said it will temporarily close Sunday after its employees were harassed for asking customers to wear masks before ordering.

item.title: Activists gather at memorial for Andres Guardado to demand sheriff release autopsy report
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: The L.A. County Sheriff's Department has put a "security hold" on Andres Guardado's autopsy and has yet to disclose what prompted a deputy to open fire on the 18-year-old.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. County Sheriff's Department has put a "security hold" on Andres Guardado's autopsy and has yet to disclose what prompted a deputy to open fire on the 18-year-old.

media:content.media:description: A photo of 18-year-old Andres Guardado is displayed by his 22-year-old sister, Jennifer, during a rally near a memorial site in Gardena on Friday. The security guard was fatally shot by a sheriff's deputy.

item.title: Coronavirus cases continue to climb in L.A. County as bars are ordered to close
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 2,542 more cases of the coronavirus and 20 related deaths. It was the county's second-highest daily total of new cases since the pandemic began.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 2,542 more cases of the coronavirus and 20 related deaths. It was the county's second-highest daily total of new cases since the pandemic began.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - JUNE 25: Bella Nousiainen, left, with daughter, Helmi Nousiainen, of Los Angeles, at the Santa Monica Pier reopens after being closed to guests for months because of the novel coronavirus pandemic on Thursday, June 25, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Chief federal judge in L.A. steps down over racially insensitive comments about Black court official
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: U.S. District Judge Cormac J. Carney cited his comments calling Black clerk Kiry Gray "street-smart" in stepping down as chief district judge. He will remain on the bench.
item.content:encoded: U.S. District Judge Cormac J. Carney cited his comments calling Black clerk Kiry Gray "street-smart" in stepping down as chief district judge. He will remain on the bench.

media:content.media:description: District Judge Cormac J. Carney ruled that decades-long delays and uncertainty about whether inmates will be executed violated the Constitution's 8th Amendment ban on cruel and unusual punishment.

item.title: Newsom orders bars closed in 7 California counties, including L.A., due to coronavirus spread
item.dc:creator: John Myers, Alex Wigglesworth, Laura Newberry, Gale Holland
item.description: Bars in these California counties are immediately affected by the state order: Los Angeles, Fresno, Kern, San Joaquin, Tulare, Kings and Imperial.
item.content:encoded: Bars in these California counties are immediately affected by the state order: Los Angeles, Fresno, Kern, San Joaquin, Tulare, Kings and Imperial.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Sunday, June 28,2020 - Patrons of the Down'n'Out Sports Bar, drink at an outside patio. Governor Newsom orders bars to close as Covid-19 cases surge in California. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Suspect identified in fatal shooting at Walmart distribution center in California
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: One person was killed Saturday when an ex-employee of a Walmart distribution center in Red Bluff, Calif., arrived and began shooting, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: One person was killed Saturday when an ex-employee of a Walmart distribution center in Red Bluff, Calif., arrived and began shooting, authorities said.

item.description: The expected plea hearing for the man accused of being a prolific rapist and serial killer will be unlike any in memory.

All 84 residents were removed. Erwig tested positive for COVID-19 and was transferred to the county hospital in Moreno Valley, RUHS, where he spent 4 weeks recovering from the coronavirus. He is now home still recuperating. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Red flag fire warnings are up for the Sacramento Valley and southeastern California

item.content:encoded: There also was a fire at the site, and the suspect appears to have rammed a vehicle into the building, dispatchers said. There were about 200 workers inside the facility.

item.title: L.A. County faces 'critical moment' as coronavirus cases keep surging
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth

item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Saturday reported a continued rise in new coronavirus cases and hospitalizations, saying the increase came at "a critical moment" in the county's reopening.

(Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Beverly Hills facing criticism after arrests of 28 peaceful protesters
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Marisa Gerber
item.description: The protest, which drew about 75 people, was the third in Beverly Hills organized by the Black Future Project, but the first that resulted in arrests, an organizer says.
item.content:encoded: The protest, which drew about 75 people, was the third in Beverly Hills organized by the Black Future Project, but the first that resulted in arrests, an organizer says.

item.description: A San Jose Police Department spokeswoman confirmed the agency was conducting an administrative investigation into the comments.
item.content:encoded: A San Jose Police Department spokeswoman confirmed the agency was conducting an administrative investigation into the comments.

item.description: The videos Facebook removed were from the Freedom Angels Foundation, known for its opposition to California's efforts to mandate vaccinations.
item.content:encoded: The videos Facebook removed were from the Freedom Angels Foundation, known for its opposition to California's efforts to mandate vaccinations.

item.content:encoded: Local and state officials met in El Centro on Saturday to create a plan to deal with a high number of coronavirus cases and hospitalizations.

item.title: A San Diego bus route provides a vital lifeline for neighborhood during pandemic
item.dc:creator: Joshua Emerson Smith
item.description: For three months, as much of life froze across San Diego, the Route 7 bus kept rumbling along, connecting City Heights to downtown San Diego.
item.content:encoded: For three months, as much of life froze across San Diego, the Route 7 bus kept rumbling along, connecting City Heights to downtown San Diego.

media:content.media:description: Christopher Castor, 56, pilots the number 7 bus that traverses University Avenue right through the heart of the City Heights neighborhood on June 17, 2020 in San Diego, California.
media:content.media:credit: Sam Hodgson / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: California cracks down on scofflaw businesses, delays reopenings as coronavirus surges
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Rong-Gong Lin II, Maura Dolan, Paul Sisson, Lori Weisberg
item.description: California officials are cracking down on scofflaw businesses and putting the brakes on reopening as coronavirus cases and hospitalizations spike.
item.content:encoded: California officials are cracking down on scofflaw businesses and putting the brakes on reopening as coronavirus cases and hospitalizations spike.

media:content.media:description: Coronavirus cases in California continued a troubling spike this week. Here, Calyssa Hill, left, and Hadley Hall, where masks while looking at their phones along the Pacific Beach boardwalk on June 24, 2020.

item.title: California Latino, Black residents hit even harder by coronavirus as white people see less danger
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: As COVID-19 cases spike, Latino and Black residents of Los Angeles County now have double the mortality rate of white residents.
item.content:encoded: As COVID-19 cases spike, Latino and Black residents of Los Angeles County now have double the mortality rate of white residents.

media:content.media:description: INGLEWOOD-CA-APRIL 15, 2020: Clarice Kavanaugh places a hand on her friend Charles Jackson's casket at Inglewood Park Cemetery in Inglewood on Wednesday, April 15, 2020. Jackson was diagnosed with covid-19 after returning home from a black ski trip in Idaho, and died days later in the hospital. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: This county voted to recognize Black Lives Matter. Then it OKd 310 more Tasers
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: As Black Lives Matter protests continue, San Mateo County this week agreed to spend $1 million on hundreds of new tasers, even as it was recognizing the BLM movement.
item.content:encoded: As Black Lives Matter protests continue, San Mateo County this week agreed to spend $1 million on hundreds of new tasers, even as it was recognizing the BLM movement.

media:content.media:description: Police Officer Patrick Richardson holds one of the Glendale Police Department's Taser guns in Glendale on Monday, June 18, 2007. The department will will soon receive new Tasers with the added capability to record more information about incidents when deployed.

item.title: Who doesn't trust Lucy Jones in a crisis? Here's what she has to say about the coronavirus pandemic
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: Lucy Jones has gotten us through many a crisis. The coronavirus pandemic may be different from an earthquake, but her analysis of it, in a new podcast, is as steady and clear as ever.
item.content:encoded: Lucy Jones has gotten us through many a crisis. The coronavirus pandemic may be different from an earthquake, but her analysis of it, in a new podcast, is as steady and clear as ever.

media:content.media:description: De Gea, Beatrice –– – Lucy Jones, a seismologist and scientist–in–charge for the Southern California for the Earthquake Hazards Team of the Geological Survey is worried about an earthquake hitting the San Andreas Fault. She thinks we could face infrastructure problems similar to New Orleans. She is photographed here in the South Mudd building at the california Institute of technology in Pasadena.

item.title: Orange County Democrats condemn 'racist' comments by John Wayne, call for airport to drop his name
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: The Democratic Party of Orange County officials passed an emergency resolution condemning film legend John Wayne's "racist and bigoted statements" and calling for an airport name change.
item.content:encoded: The Democratic Party of Orange County officials passed an emergency resolution condemning film legend John Wayne's "racist and bigoted statements" and calling for an airport name change.

media:content.media:description: Boster, Mark   123034.ME.0417.JohnWayne.MJB(Newport Beach)Silver screen legend John Wayne is immortalized in a bronze statue on the baggage level at the Orange County Airport bearing his name. However, Newport Beach wants to fete Wayne on his 100th birthday, but can't throw a party at his old house in Newport because the structure was torn down by the new residencts. The Duke's final resting place, the statue at the airport and a bar in Newport appear to be the last honors in a town that he called home.April 16, 2007

item.title: Column: As coronavirus surges, more stores are going cashless. The price tag is racism
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: As we rush into a "cashless" society to slow the coronavirus, know that there are trade-offs. Businesses could make existing racial inequities worse.
item.content:encoded: As we rush into a "cashless" society to slow the coronavirus, know that there are trade-offs. Businesses could make existing racial inequities worse.

media:content.media:description: This Thursday, May 2, 2019, photo shows a sign posted on a door alerting customers that cash is not accepted at Freshroll Vietnamese Rolls and Bowls in San Francisco. San Francisco is about to require brick-and-mortar retailers to take cash in payment for goods, joining Philadelphia and New Jersey in banning a practice that critics say discriminates against the poor. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

item.title: Coronavirus infection rate spiking in California, a troubling sign of community spread
item.dc:creator: Sean Greene, Rong-Gong Lin II, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Of the many coronavirus metrics rising in California, one of the most troubling is the rate in which coronavirus test results are now coming back positive.
item.content:encoded: Of the many coronavirus metrics rising in California, one of the most troubling is the rate in which coronavirus test results are now coming back positive.

media:content.media:description: Angelica and Julio Rascon of Tucson Arizona visited Mission Beach on Friday. Very few people were seen wearing masks on the beach on June 26th, 2020 in San Diego, California.
media:content.media:credit: Jarrod Valliere / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Column One: A life recovered, then taken by coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Isaiah Murtaugh
item.description: Gaspar Gomez, 51, died of COVID-19 in April. He is the first known day laborer to have died from the disease. This is his story.
item.content:encoded: Gaspar Gomez, 51, died of COVID-19 in April. He is the first known day laborer to have died from the disease. This is his story.

media:content.media:description: Gaspar Gomez coffin sits ready for burial in a North Hollywood cemetery. Gomez died on May 3 after a month-long battle with coronavirus. (Photo c/o Lucy Gomez)

item.title: Family of man killed by LAPD officer after South L.A. collision demands answers
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda
item.description: The Latino Coalition of L.A. held a press conference Friday to demand justice and law enforcement cooperation in the killing of Daniel Hernandez.
item.content:encoded: The Latino Coalition of L.A. held a press conference Friday to demand justice and law enforcement cooperation in the killing of Daniel Hernandez.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - JUNE 26, 2020. Matthew Hernandez, 8, holds a sign with a picture of his uncle, Daniel Hernandez, during a press conference at the L.A. County Hall of Justice on Friday, June 26, 2020. Daniel Hernandez was fatally shot by members of the LAPD in South Los Angeles. The Latino Coialition of Los Angeles is calling for complete and transparent investigations iof officers who have shot and killed Latinos and Blacks. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California will use surplus cash, delay school funds in $202.1-billion budget sent to Newsom
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: California lawmakers sent a $202.1-billion state budget to Gov. Gavin Newsom on Friday, a spending plan crafted to erase a historic deficit triggered by the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers sent a $202.1-billion state budget to Gov. Gavin Newsom on Friday, a spending plan crafted to erase a historic deficit triggered by the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: Sen. Holly Mitchell, D-Los Angeles, chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, gets an elbow bump from Sen. Robert Hertzberg, D-Los Angeles, after the Senate approved the $202.1 billion state budget at the Capitol in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, June 25, 2020. Mitchell carried the bills that made up the spending plan that covers the state's estimated $54.3 billion deficit brought on by the coronavirus. The Assembly is scheduled to vote on the budget Friday. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: L.A. will resume ticketing during street sweeping next month
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: Parking tickets on street sweeping days in Los Angeles will return July 6, the Transportation Department said.
item.content:encoded: Parking tickets on street sweeping days in Los Angeles will return July 6, the Transportation Department said.

media:content.media:description: Parking mistakes will be taking a bite out of drivers' budgets to help the city's.

item.title: Column: Go ahead, cut the police budget. But more important, remake the LAPD
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez

item.content:encoded: Not convinced the LAPD needs a do-over? Check out the social media feed of one of its union leaders.

(Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Francisco pauses reopening plans because of coronavirus surge
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Businesses like hair salons, zoos and outdoor bars that were scheduled to reopen Monday will now stay closed, the San Francisco health director said, amid a surge in infection rates.
item.content:encoded: Businesses like hair salons, zoos and outdoor bars that were scheduled to reopen Monday will now stay closed, the San Francisco health director said, amid a surge in infection rates.

item.title: Charles Webb, who inspired a Hollywood classic with 'The Graduate,' dies at 81
item.dc:creator: Steve Marble
item.description: Although the 1967 movie made millions, Webb lived in poverty. The writer gave away his earnings, inheritance and the occasional house he bought, calling it a "purifying experience" to run out of money.
item.content:encoded: Although the 1967 movie made millions, Webb lived in poverty. The writer gave away his earnings, inheritance and the occasional house he bought, calling it a "purifying experience" to run out of money.

media:content.media:description: Charles Webb, author of 'The Graduate' photographed in Brighton, UK3rd February 2005. (Photo by Andrew Hasson/Photoshot/Getty Images)

item.title: Coronavirus caught us off guard. Here's what disaster preppers say we needed to do all along

item.description: Californians live in the land of wildfires, earthquakes and other natural disasters. Here's what we can learn from people who take preparedness very seriously.
item.content:encoded: Californians live in the land of wildfires, earthquakes and other natural disasters. Here's what we can learn from people who take preparedness very seriously.

item.title: Prosecutors have received at least 25 new allegations against adult film star Ron Jeremy

item.title: Video shows fireworks exploding in car during Riverside protest
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan

item.content:encoded: Riverside police have arrested a man they say lit a firecracker and tossed it at protesters in Riverside this month, only to have the incendiary device thrown back into his car and explode.

item.title: California's unemployment agency targeted for audit as criticism grows

item.content:encoded: California's unemployment agency is facing a barrage of bipartisan criticism from lawmakers over continuing delays in approving jobless claims.

media:content.media:description: A job seeker waits to use a phone at a career center in Richmond, Calif. Economist Jack Kyser predicts that the state's jobless rate will average 12.6% next year, but other economists call his prediction overly pessimistic.

item.title: Santa Cruz becomes the first U.S. city to ban predictive policing
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: The city has permanently banished the use of data to predict where crimes occur, a practice that critics say often led to racist policing.
item.content:encoded: The city has permanently banished the use of data to predict where crimes occur, a practice that critics say often led to racist policing.

media:content.media:description: Police secure the scene. The loss of the two officers follows a recent series of violent incidents in the city and was especially devastating for the small Police Department, which has about 90 sworn officers.

item.content:encoded: More Californians will vote by mail this year because of the coronavirus. Here's how it works.

The special election, between Democrat Christy Smith and Republican Mike Garcia, is for California's 25th congressional district seat that was formerly held by Katie Hill. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: The USC campus. School officials violated federal labor rules by interfering with a high-profile vote to decide whether hundreds of its faculty members should form a union, according to the National Labor Relations Board.

item.description: Officials say in-car pickup for online orders will resume Monday. The popular bakery's other locations remain open.
item.content:encoded: Officials say in-car pickup for online orders will resume Monday. The popular bakery's other locations remain open.

media:content.media:description: Downey's downtown withered with the decline of the aerospace industry in the 1990s, but recent arrivals such as Porto's bakery are breathing new life into the area.

item.title: L.A. to pay nearly $1 million in settlement against officer who shot Black teen in back
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The claim stems from a 2015 shooting in which an LAPD officer shot at a group of teens who were rapping and dancing in an alley while holding a toy gun.
item.content:encoded: The claim stems from a 2015 shooting in which an LAPD officer shot at a group of teens who were rapping and dancing in an alley while holding a toy gun.

media:content.media:description: Jamar Nicholson shows a bullet wound on his back. Nicholson was shot Feb. 10 in an alley in South L.A. by an LAPD officer.

item.title: Trump broke the law by using military funds for border wall, appeals court rules
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: In a major border wall ruling, the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals says the Trump administration broke the law using defense funds for wall construction.
item.content:encoded: In a major border wall ruling, the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals says the Trump administration broke the law using defense funds for wall construction.

media:content.media:description: A man stands outside the main door outside the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals building Thursday, Feb. 9, 2017, in San Francisco. A federal appeals court refused Thursday to reinstate President Donald Trump's ban on travelers from seven predominantly Muslim nations, dealing another legal setback to the new administration's immigration policy. (AP Photo/Marcio Jose Sanchez)

item.title: Immigrants detained at Adelanto staged a peaceful protest. Guards in riot gear pepper-sprayed them
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: Immigration and Customs Enforcement said more than 150 detainees became disruptive and refused directives from staff, necessitating "the use of non-lethal force to preserve order" after attempts at deescalation were unsuccessful.
item.content:encoded: Immigration and Customs Enforcement said more than 150 detainees became disruptive and refused directives from staff, necessitating "the use of non-lethal force to preserve order" after attempts at deescalation were unsuccessful.

media:content.media:description: ADELANTO, CA - NOVEMBER 15: A guard escorts an immigrant detainee from his 'segregation cell' back into the general population at the Adelanto Detention Facility on November 15, 2013 in Adelanto, California. Most detainees in segregation cells are sent there for fighting with other immigrants, according to guards. The facility, the largest and newest Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), detention center in California, houses an average of 1,100 immigrants in custody pending a decision in their immigration cases or awaiting deportation. The average stay for a detainee is 29 days. The facility is managed by the private GEO Group. ICE detains an average of 33,000 undocumented immigrants in more than 400 facilities nationwide. (Photo by John Moore/Getty Images)

item.title: Black doll found hanged in South Lake Tahoe among nooses discovered around state
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Californians over the last week have found and reported three nooses in South Lake Tahoe, Santa Clarita and Sonoma.
item.content:encoded: Californians over the last week have found and reported three nooses in South Lake Tahoe, Santa Clarita and Sonoma.

media:content.media:description: A disfigured Black doll hangs hanged on a noose suspended from a South Lake Tahoe power line on Tuesday.

item.title: San Quentin prison coronavirus outbreak 'tragic, predictable and unacceptable'
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Sean Greene
item.description: More than 500 inmates at the prison in Marin County have tested positive for COVID-19, many of them after transferring from the men's prison in Chino, the site of a massive coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: More than 500 inmates at the prison in Marin County have tested positive for COVID-19, many of them after transferring from the men's prison in Chino, the site of a massive coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: A cellblock at San Quentin State Prison in April. More than 80 inmates became sick with pneumonia during an outbreak of Legionnaire's disease. The bacteria was traced to the prison medical building.

item.title: More evidence emerges of the coronavirus slipping in through LAX
item.dc:creator: Kiera Feldman, Harriet Ryan
item.description: The Times has now identified a third flight into LAX in which public health officials in the early stage of the COVID-19 pandemic did not alert travelers that they were at risk for infection.
item.content:encoded: The Times has now identified a third flight into LAX in which public health officials in the early stage of the COVID-19 pandemic did not alert travelers that they were at risk for infection.

Due to global pandemic and upcoming Memorial Day Weekend travelers are strongly advised to follow mask and social distancing recommendations at Los Angeles International Airport. Los Angeles Airport LAX on Friday, May 22, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: It's boom times for sign makers. So why aren't they making more money?
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: The coronavirus crisis has increased demand for outdoor signs. But that doesn't mean sign makers are raking it in.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus crisis has increased demand for outdoor signs. But that doesn't mean sign makers are raking it in.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA - MAY 21: Akihiro Tsuneizumi paint a window sign at Gunthers on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Santa Ana, CA. Signmakers - people who paint windows, make banners or A-frames, and other such stuff - has exploded as businesses try everything to get customers during coronavirus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.content:encoded: High school and college commencements have become a mobile rite of passage amid COVID-19 restrictions.

(Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: The slow progress in handing out state money has done little to improve the plight of many Californians whose immigration status makes them ineligible for regular jobless benefits.

item.title: Despite alarming California coronavirus spike, don't expect stay-at-home orders to quickly return
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Sean Greene
item.description: Despite an alarming spike in both coronavirus cases and hospitalizations, California health officials appear to have little appetite at least right now for a widespread retreat from reopening of the economy.
item.content:encoded: Despite an alarming spike in both coronavirus cases and hospitalizations, California health officials appear to have little appetite at least right now for a widespread retreat from reopening of the economy.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Morgan Eales, girlfriend of owner/founder Kyle Thille posts new signs of opening at Ventura Coast Brewing Company on the corner of South Oak Street and East Santa Clara St in downtown Ventura as Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California confronts its racist past as tributes to Confederates and colonizers fall
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: California confronts its racist, colonial past as statues fall, mascots are renamed and a town debates changing its name that honors a Confederate general.
item.content:encoded: California confronts its racist, colonial past as statues fall, mascots are renamed and a town debates changing its name that honors a Confederate general.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 20: Activists topple the statue of Father Junipero Serra (1713 - 1784) at Father Serra Park in El Pueblo de Los Angeles on Saturday, June 20, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Junipero Serra, a Roman Catholic Spanish priest, who found the first nine of 21 Spanish missions in California from San Diego to San Francisco, in what was then Alta California in the Province of Las Californias, New Spain. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: During the pandemic, groups that help kids are hurting. Kids are, too
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: Make-A-Wish and other organizations that help children are raising less money. Social workers and court services for families also face challenges.
item.content:encoded: Make-A-Wish and other organizations that help children are raising less money. Social workers and court services for families also face challenges.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 23: Kayla Diaz, 12, tosses the football with her mom at Point Fermin Park in San Pedro on Tuesday, June 23, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. After spending the majority of the last several months in doors to protect their compromised immune systems, they have found solace in coming to the park for fresh air occasionally. Before the coronavirus pandemic broke out, Kayla wished to go to Hawaii to go swimming after completing chemotherapy last year through Make-A-Wish. Due to a chemo port in her chest, she wasn't able to swim for the longest time, which is one of her favorite hobbies. Her wish was going to be in April but is now postponed. Marlene, is a hair dresser and is now out of work due to the coronavirus outbreak. She had a baby in January and was just getting back to work when everything hit. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'He is our pit bull': LAPD union boss embodies force's troubled past as he touts reform
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: Jamie McBride is an unrepentant backer of old-school policing. He loves former chief Daryl Gates. He says Black Lives Matter is the real problem. And he is the recent face of the LAPD union.
item.content:encoded: Jamie McBride is an unrepentant backer of old-school policing. He loves former chief Daryl Gates. He says Black Lives Matter is the real problem. And he is the recent face of the LAPD union.

media:content.media:description: Jamie McBride, a Los Angeles police detective and a director of Los Angeles Police Protective League, speaks at a news conference last year. A jury awarded McBride $1.5 million in his lawsuit alleging he was the victim of retaliation by the department.

item.title: Feds say tower project shows toll of bribery in Huizar case: Less affordable housing
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, David Zahniser
item.description: Prosecutors allege that L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar schemed with the developer of an Arts District project and its lobbyist to provide "direct and indirect financial benefits" to the councilman in exchange for his help at City Hall.
item.content:encoded: Prosecutors allege that L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar schemed with the developer of an Arts District project and its lobbyist to provide "direct and indirect financial benefits" to the councilman in exchange for his help at City Hall.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles Councilman Jose Huizar's district includes Boyle Heights, El Sereno, Eagle Rock and much of downtown.

item.title: Former law enforcement officers appear to plot to kill police critic and activist Shaun King
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Prominent police critic and activist Shaun King published a blog post Thursday detailing steps of a plot to kill him by several former local law enforcement officers. The original posts are under investigation.
item.content:encoded: Prominent police critic and activist Shaun King published a blog post Thursday detailing steps of a plot to kill him by several former local law enforcement officers. The original posts are under investigation.

media:content.media:description: A report posted on a conservative website asserts that Shaun King, a civil rights activist and prominent figure in the Black Lives Matter movement, "is white and has been lying about his ethnicity for years."

item.title: Sheriff's deputy who fatally shot Andres Guardado faced earlier allegations
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian, Maya Lau
item.description: The Compton sheriff's deputy who shot and killed Andres Guardado is identified as Miguel Vega.
item.content:encoded: The Compton sheriff's deputy who shot and killed Andres Guardado is identified as Miguel Vega.

media:content.media:description: COMPTON, CALIF. - JUNE 25, 2020. Protesters in cars drive around the Compton Civic Center on Thursday, June 25, 2020, following a police shooting that resulted in the death of Andres Guardado, 18. Guardado was killed by Sheriff's deputies last week at an auto shop in Gardena. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. Metro board pushes police reform, seeks to shift funds to homeless outreach
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: L.A. transit officials say they are beginning to change how the system is policed, with plans to move away from armed response to some nonviolent crimes and to devote more funds to homeless outreach.
item.content:encoded: L.A. transit officials say they are beginning to change how the system is policed, with plans to move away from armed response to some nonviolent crimes and to devote more funds to homeless outreach.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - JUNE 25: LAPD officers E. Rosales, left, and D. Castro, patrol the Metro Red Line at the Hollywood/Highland Metro Station Thursday, June 25, 2020 in Hollywood, CA. The Metro Board of Directors held a meeting Thursday where the agenda included the consideration of appointing a committee to develop plans for replacing armed transit safety officers with ``smarter and more effective methods of providing public safety.'' Metro security is staffed by multiple agencies, including the L.A. County Sheriff's Department and L.A. and Long Beach police departments, transit security guards and contract security workers. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: City attorney drops all charges against anti-Trump protest group that LAPD spied on
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: After three years and multiple retrials, the city attorney's office has dropped charges against a group of protesters who blocked the 101 Freeway in 2017. The prosecution led to the revelation that the LAPD had sent an informant to infiltrate the non-violent protest group, Refuse Fascism.
item.content:encoded: After three years and multiple retrials, the city attorney's office has dropped charges against a group of protesters who blocked the 101 Freeway in 2017. The prosecution led to the revelation that the LAPD had sent an informant to infiltrate the non-violent protest group, Refuse Fascism.

item.title: Proposal slashes L.A. County Sheriff's Department budget by $162 million

item.content:encoded: First proposed budget reflecting pandemic-related economic woes would slash spending at Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department by $162.1 million and result in 451 layoffs.

item.title: New alarms raised as California coronavirus hospitalizations jump 32% in two weeks

item.title: Santa Cruz County lifts beach closures: 'People are not willing to be governed'
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The county, which has upheld some of the state's strictest shelter-in-place guidelines longer than many other locales in California, will lift all beach closures at midnight.
item.content:encoded: The county, which has upheld some of the state's strictest shelter-in-place guidelines longer than many other locales in California, will lift all beach closures at midnight.

media:content.media:description: SANTA CRUZ, CA -- MAY 08: Beachgoers at Lighthouse Field State Beach on Friday, May 8, 2020, in Santa Cruz, CA. As the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Santa Cruz County continue to rise the City of Santa Cruz is taking necessary precautionary efforts to contain the spread of this virus and mitigate its impact. City of Santa Cruz beaches will be closed from 11:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., daily until further notice. The ocean will remain open for water sports (e.g., surfing, boogie-boarding, swimming, paddle-boarding, kayaking, boating, etc.), and individuals may cross beaches in order to access and leave the ocean. All other non-exercise, passive, or sedentary activities at beaches, such as sitting, lying, standing, picnicking, etc, are prohibited. Please continue to observe safe distancing while at our beaches. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mother of Vanessa Marquez files wrongful death lawsuit against South Pasadena, police
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The mother of actress Vanessa Marquez, who was shot to death by police at her South Pasadena home in August 2018, files a wrongful death lawsuit.
item.content:encoded: The mother of actress Vanessa Marquez, who was shot to death by police at her South Pasadena home in August 2018, files a wrongful death lawsuit.

media:content.media:description: ER -- "February 5, 1995" Episode 15 -- Air Date 02/02/1995 -- Pictured: Vanessa Marquez as Nurse Wendy Goldman -- Photo by: Alice S. Hall/NBCU Photo Bank
media:content.media:credit: Alice S. Hall / NBCU Photo Bank

item.title: Mountain lion is captured after spending the night under Monrovia home
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan, Irfan Khan
item.description: The cougar had been prowling around the neighborhood for the past week but was cornered Thursday and tranquilized by Fish and Wildlife officials.
item.content:encoded: The cougar had been prowling around the neighborhood for the past week but was cornered Thursday and tranquilized by Fish and Wildlife officials.

media:content.media:description: Wildlife officials captured a mountain lion Thursday morning that was hiding in the crawl space of a Monrovia home. The big cat was initially spotted near the intersection of West Colorado Boulevard and Monterey Avenue.(Photo by Silvia Escobar)

item.title: L.A. mayor urges residents to stay home as coronavirus cases spike
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Taryn Luna
item.description: There have been nearly 90,000 confirmed coronavirus infections and more than 3,200 deaths in Los Angeles County.
item.content:encoded: There have been nearly 90,000 confirmed coronavirus infections and more than 3,200 deaths in Los Angeles County.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA-MAY 14, 2020: Background left to right-Friends Joshua Andrew, 32, of Chicago, Illinois, Bryan Hawn, 32, and Vlad Parker, 29, both of Santa Monica, wear masks to protect against the coronavirus while walking with others doing the same along the boardwalk in Venice Beach. A new rule, announced by Mayor Eric Garcetti on Wednesday, now requires face masks for all outdoor activities. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Californians are desperate to see friends and family. Officials debate how to do so safely
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: While L.A. County continues to ban gatherings beyond protests or religious services, the Bay Area is beginning to allow small group meet-ups.
item.content:encoded: While L.A. County continues to ban gatherings beyond protests or religious services, the Bay Area is beginning to allow small group meet-ups.

media:content.media:description: NEWPORT BEACH, CA - JUNE 22: Sandra Lopez, right, with Estrella Perez, 3, watch as Yuleini Perez, 7, left, and Viviana Perez, all of La Habra, take in a scenic view of Newport Harbor on a nice summer day at Lookout Point Monday, June 22, 2020 at Corona Del Mar in Newport Beach, CA. Elevated coronavirus transmissions and related hospitalizations are worsening in some parts of California, and a failure to wear masks in public and increased gatherings are partly to blame, health officials said. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Santa Monica Pier reopens, but you can't go on the Ferris wheel
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: The Santa Monica Pier will reopen with limited hours and there will be limits to the number of visitors allowed at one time to encourage social distancing.
item.content:encoded: The Santa Monica Pier will reopen with limited hours and there will be limits to the number of visitors allowed at one time to encourage social distancing.

media:content.media:description: The ferris wheel at the Santa Monica Pier.
media:content.media:credit: Carolina A. Miranda / Los Angeles Times

item.title: New emergency evacuation guidelines won't include 'mandatory' or 'voluntary' labels
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: State officials are recommending standard terminology for cities and counties in issuing evacuation "warnings" and "orders" during emergencies.
item.content:encoded: State officials are recommending standard terminology for cities and counties in issuing evacuation "warnings" and "orders" during emergencies.

media:content.media:description: MALIBU, CA - NOVEMBER 9, 2018 - - A firefighter tries to put out the flames on a burning home from the Woolsey fire on Dume Drive in Malibu on November 9, 2018. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: How do you foster 'a good death in a racist society?'
item.dc:creator: Chace Beech
item.description: Alua Arthur is a death doula, someone who helps people prepare for death, much as birth doulas help mothers prepare to give birth. She is Black, and the death of George Floyd hit hard for her and other Black death doulas, who saw in his death the antithesis of the "good death" they are trying to foster. She and five other women hosted a talk: "Sayin' It Louder; A Conversation about a Good Death in a Racist Society."
item.content:encoded: Alua Arthur is a death doula, someone who helps people prepare for death, much as birth doulas help mothers prepare to give birth. She is Black, and the death of George Floyd hit hard for her and other Black death doulas, who saw in his death the antithesis of the "good death" they are trying to foster. She and five other women hosted a talk: "Sayin' It Louder; A Conversation about a Good Death in a Racist Society."

media:content.media:description: Alua Arthur with Beverly Leacock.(Gen McKinney , courtesy of Alua Arthur.)
media:content.media:credit: Gen McKinney , courtesy of Alua Arthur.

item.title: Sheriff asks attorney general to monitor shooting while stonewalling inspector general
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Two institutions overseeing the Sheriff's Department say they are running into roadblocks.
item.content:encoded: Two institutions overseeing the Sheriff's Department say they are running into roadblocks.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 24, 2019: L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva speaks during a media open house at the Hall of Justice in Los Angeles, Calif., on April 24, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Bicycles have enjoyed a boom during the pandemic. Will it last as car traffic resumes?
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Bicycle sales and ridership skyrocketed as people were forced to stay home during the pandemic, resulting in much less car traffic on city streets. Will Americans stick with it?
item.content:encoded: Bicycle sales and ridership skyrocketed as people were forced to stay home during the pandemic, resulting in much less car traffic on city streets. Will Americans stick with it?

media:content.media:description: Cyclists participate in a George Floyd solidarity ride on Friday, June 5, 2020, in San Francisco. Floyd died after being restrained by Minneapolis police officers on May 25.(AP Photo/Ben Margot)

item.title: 'Mind-blowing.' Eastside residents, community leaders react to the Jose Huizar case
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Ruben Vives
item.description: L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar's life story had been an inspiration to many, not just on the Eastside but across the city. Now he faces a federal racketeering charge.
item.content:encoded: L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar's life story had been an inspiration to many, not just on the Eastside but across the city. Now he faces a federal racketeering charge.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles City Councilman Jose Huizar, shown at a council meeting in February, has been accused by a former aide of sexual harassment.

item.title: L.A. Times faces painful reckoning over race in its staff and pages
item.dc:creator: Meg James, Daniel Hernandez
item.description: Two years after the Los Angeles Times reverted to local ownership, the country's largest metropolitan daily newspaper is facing a painful internal reckoning over glaring deficiencies and missteps regarding race and representation in its pages and its staff.
item.content:encoded: Two years after the Los Angeles Times reverted to local ownership, the country's largest metropolitan daily newspaper is facing a painful internal reckoning over glaring deficiencies and missteps regarding race and representation in its pages and its staff.

media:content.media:description: EL SEGUNDO, CA - JUNE 24: Los Angeles Times Executive Editor Norman Pearlstine holds a virtual company town hall, titled, "Newsroom Update: discussion about racism, diversity and inclusiveness," and is seen broadcasting from the video studio, of the company's El Segundo, CA, headquarters, Wednesday, June 24, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Shooting at Santa Ana cemetery leaves one person dead
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: A shooting at Santa Ana Cemetery on Wednesday left one man dead and one injured.
item.content:encoded: A shooting at Santa Ana Cemetery on Wednesday left one man dead and one injured.

media:content.media:description: LS.Cemeteries1 /18/96Palm trees surround the graves and headstones in Santa Ana Cemetary which is located on Santa Clara Ave. in Santa Ana. KODAK A

item.title: In nod to criticism, L.A. County law enforcement agencies discussing joint investigations of police killings
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Richard Winton, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Amid growing skepticism for police agencies that investigate killings by their own officers, top law enforcement officials in the Los Angeles region have reached a tentative agreement to cede the work instead to a centralized task force.
item.content:encoded: Amid growing skepticism for police agencies that investigate killings by their own officers, top law enforcement officials in the Los Angeles region have reached a tentative agreement to cede the work instead to a centralized task force.

media:content.media:description: Two Los Angeles police officers face charges of repeatedly sexually assaulting four women.

item.title: Tristan Eaton's Highland Park mural of MLK was defaced. He repainted Malcolm X
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Tristan Eaton's Martin Luther King Jr. Mural at Highland Park's Cafe de Leche was vandalized with racial slurs. The artist repainted Malcolm X hours later.
item.content:encoded: Tristan Eaton's Martin Luther King Jr. Mural at Highland Park's Cafe de Leche was vandalized with racial slurs. The artist repainted Malcolm X hours later.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - JUNE 23: Tristan Eaton repaints his Malcolm X mural that was defaced on Tuesday, June 23, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Woman injured in shooting of Terron Boone files civil rights claim
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Shellondra Thomas, the woman injured by deputies in the shooting of Terron Boone, filed a civil rights claim against the county.
item.content:encoded: Shellondra Thomas, the woman injured by deputies in the shooting of Terron Boone, filed a civil rights claim against the county.

media:content.media:description: Terron Boone
